Description: Streaked, pale brown and white-grey quartz, chalcedony cylinder seal (white patination was probably acquired during burial). A bearded figure whose head is badly damaged by a chip, stands facing left with his right hand raised and his left arm bent; he wears a long robe draped over his left shoulder, with a vertical edge down the front and a curved hem. Seven-line cuneiform inscription. Two frontal antelope heads flank the god. Line borders top and bottom.
Curator's comments: Matthews (p. 86) attributes this seal to the First Kassite Central Tradition, and (p. 25 n. 277) specifies that horns of this type are common on detached animal heads used as filling motifs on First Kassite and pseudo-Kassite seals.
Bibliographic references: Matthews, D M 1990 / Principals of Composition in Near Eastern Glyptic of the Later 2nd Millenium BC (pp. 25, 86.)
Condition: Ends slightly convex and edges badly chipped, particularly the upper (aggravated by faults in the stone) probably due to the forcible removal of decorative metal (gold?) caps.
Acquisition name: From: Sir Ernest A T Wallis Budge
